Package dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.ant

NG Generator Ant Tasks The NG generator defines a set of tasks for Apache Ant which can be composed in arbitrary build scripts.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    IJavaGenTemplate
    A JavaGen generator must implement this interface.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    JavaGenContext
    This class is handed to a IJavaGenTemplate or a Jet template.

Package dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.ant Description

NG Generator Ant Tasks

The NG generator defines a set of tasks for Apache Ant which can be composed in arbitrary build scripts. A build script must be delivered with the plugin and registered as generator at extension point dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.plugin.generator. Thus this is the standard extension point for registering generators that requires a class implementing the dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.generator.ICodeGenerator interface you must specify the dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.NGGenerator here. The build script is defined as parameter to the NGGenerator.

Example:

<extension point="dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.plugin.generator"
           id="NGGeneratorAPITest_TS_generator_id"
           name="NGGeneratorAPITest_TS Generator">

    <generator id="CanIfTestGenerator"
               moduleId="CanIf"
               class="dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.NGGenerator">

        <parameter mode="generate" 
                   name="buildfile" 
                   value="scripts/CanIf_build.xml"/> 
    </generator>
  
</extension>

Defined Ant Tasks

ng.tmplgen
ng.extgen
ng.jetgen
ng.javagen
ng.jetgen.src
ng.javagen.src
ng.property
ng.setgeneratorvar
ng.getgeneratorvar

ng.tmplgen

The ng.tmplgen task runs a classic template based code generator from an Ant script. The template file to process is defined by the attribute template. It is possible to redirect the default DCtxt handle to a DCtxt variable specified by the optional attribute model. Be sure that this DCtxt variable exists before the generator runs. It is possible to pass arbitrary variables to the generator that are defined by nested variable tags.

Attribute Description Required
template The path to the code template relative to the root directory of the plugin. Yes
file The output file either absolute or relative to the output directory specified in the context of this code generator. A default output file will be taken when omitted. No
dctxt Name of a DCtxt variable. If this is a module-bound generator then the DCtxt already points to the module configuration of the specified module (attribute "moduleId" at the "dreisoft.tresos.generator.api.plugin.generator" extension point) and this attribute should be omitted. If a dctxt is defined here then a DCtxt variable must exist with this value, otherwise the task will fail. No
needCodeTags Defines whether tag [!CODE!] is needed to start writing code, default is false. No, defaults to false.
failonerror Flag to indicate whether to halt the build in case of an error. The default value is true. No, defaults to true.
Nested Elements Description Required
include Defines further include paths relative to the plugin's root folder where to search files when processing include tags. No
variable Optional variables that are set to the XPath context and can be evaluated by the template based code generator. No

Example:

The following example causes the template based code generator to process the template file CanIf_Cfg.h under the templates folder that in turn is relative to the plugin root. The resulting file CanIf_Cfg.h is generated to the default output directory specified in variable VARIABLE_OUTPUT_DIR of CodeGeneratorContext.

<ng.tmplgen template="templates/CanIf_Cfg.h"
            file="CanIf_Cfg.h"
            needCodeTags="true"> 
  
    <include path="generate" />
  
    <variable name="var1" value="foo" />
    <variable name="var2" value="bar" />
</ng.tmplgen>

ng.extgen

The ng.extgen task runs an external generator. An external generator can be any arbitrary executeable or script that can be processed by a command line interpreter (e.g. cmd.exe, sh). Before the executeable is started the engine will run an epc file generator whose result is intended to be the data basis for the external generator. Before executing the given command the external generator substitutes known placeholder like ${pluginPath} or ${outputDir}. Thus Ant uses the same syntax for its properties please be aware to to escape any dollar sign (by another one), e.g. $${outputDir}.

Attribute Description Required
commandline The command line to execute with the command and arguments. Yes
cfgFilePath The output directory for the epc files generated by the epc file generator that is executed before the external generator runs. A default directory will be used when omitted. No
contentType Defines the content type of the generated epc files (e.g. "asc:2.0"). A default content type will be used when omitted. No
generateAllModules Determines whether all modules shall be generated or only the module defined at the generator extension point, default is false. No, defaults to false.
generateIntoOneFile Determines whether the modules shall be generated into one single file or in seperate files, default is false. No, defaults to false.
workingDir The working directory for the external generator. A default working dir will be used when omitted. No
shell Determines whether to run in a command shell (e.g. cmd.exe, sh), default is false. No, defaults to false.
timeout The timeout in seconds. A default timeout will be used when omitted. No
error Pattern for standard output to interpret as error message. No
warning Pattern for standard output to interpret as warning message. No
info Pattern for standard output to interpret as info message. No
failonerror Flag to indicate whether to halt the build in case of an error. The default value is true. No, defaults to true
Nested Elements Description Required
variable Optional variables that are set to the XPath context and can affect the epc file generation. No

Example:

The following example first generates all module configurations found in the underlying project into one file (that is called project.epc by default) under directory epcFiles that in turn is relative to the default output directory (defined in CodeGeneratorContext.VARIABLE_OUTPUT_DIR). After this the specified commandline is executed.

<ng.extgen commandline="$${pluginPath}/bin/gen.exe -f $${outputDir}/epcFiles/project.epc -o $${outputDir}/src/CanIf_Cfg.c"
           cfgFilePath="epcFiles"
           generateAllModules="true"
           generateIntoOneFile="true"
           error="^\s*Error\[$$f,$$l\]:\s*$$m\s*$$" />

ng.jetgen

The ng.jetgen task runs a single jet template. This template must be already compiled as class file and in the classpath of the plugin that registered the generator. The jet template class to run is defined by the class attribute. The file attribute defines the generated file relative to the output directory specified in variable VARIABLE_OUTPUT_DIR of CodeGeneratorContext. It is possible to pass arbitrary arguments to the generator that are defined by nested argument tags.

Attribute Description Required
class The fully-qualified class name of the jet template to run. Yes
file The output file either absolute or relative to the output directory specified in the context of this code generator. A default output file will be taken when omitted. No
failonerror Flag to indicate whether to halt the build in case of an error. The default value is true. No, defaults to true
Nested Elements Description Required
argument An argument consists of a name and value (both String) and is passed to the generator. The number of specified arguments is not restricted. No

Example:

The following example runs the class dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.test.jet.generated.JetGenerator and writes its output to file JetGenTask.txt under the output directory of the generator. The JetGenerator class must be a compiled Java class that was originally a jet template and generated to a Java source file. The optional arguments useDet and someArg are passed to the generator and can be accessed as variable of the generator context.

<ng.jetgen class="dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.test.jet.generated.JetGenerator"
           file="JetGenTask.txt"
           failonerror="false">
  <argument name="useDet" value="true" />
  <argument name="someArg" value="123" />
</ng.jetgen>

ng.javagen

This ant task is similar to the ng.jetgen task but runs a single java class instead of a jet template. The class must implement the dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.ant.IJavaGenTemplate interface to call method generate(JavaGenContext). It must be delivered as compiled Java class and in the classpath of the plugin that registered the generator.

Attribute Description Required
class The fully-qualified class name of the class to run. It must implement dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.ant.IJavaGenTemplate Yes
file The output file either absolute or relative to the output directory specified in the context of this code generator. A default output file will be taken when omitted. No
failonerror Flag to indicate whether to halt the build in case of an error. The default value is true. No, defaults to true.
Nested Elements Description Required
argument An argument consists of a name and value (both String) and is passed to the generator. The number of specified arguments is not restricted. No

Examples:

The following example runs the generator dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.test.generator.JavaGenTestGenerator and writes its output to file JavaGenTask.txt under the output directory of the generator. It is possible to pass arguments to the generator as nested argument tags.

<ng.javagen class="dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.test.generator.JavaGenTestGenerator" file="JavaGenTask.txt" />

ng.jetgen.src

The ng.jetgen.src task runs a single jet template that is delivered as source and will be compiled first before execution. The jet template to compile is specified by nested jetIncludes tags which are implemented as ant filesets (for more information about filesets refer to the ant user manual). Even there will be only one template class executed (specified by attribute class) there can be any number of template source file specified by jetIncludes fileset(s) that all will be compiled first to java source and to class files. The classpath of the plugin that registered the generator is used for compilation and for execution. It is possible to define further java source files within nested javaIncludes tags (fileset) that will be compiled and join the classpath for the compilation and execution of the jet template.

Attribute Description Required
class The fully-qualified class name of the jet template to run after its compilation. Yes
file The output file either absolute or relative to the output directory specified in the context of this code generator. A default output file will be taken when omitted. No
failonerror Flag to indicate whether to halt the build in case of an error. The default value is true. No, defaults to true.
Nested Elements Description Required
jetIncludes Fileset(s) defining jet templates to compile. Yes
javaIncludes Optional fileset(s) defining java source files to compile and to append to the classpath of the jet compilation and execution. No
argument An argument consists of a name and value (both String) and is passed to the generator. The number of specified arguments is not restricted. No

Examples:

The following example runs the jet generator class dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.test.jet.generated.JetGenerator after compiling it. The nested jetIncludes define the source jet template(s) that will be generated and compiled. Optional javaIncludes define java source files that will be compiled together with the jet generated Java sources and build an additional classpath for the generator. The nested argument tags are passed to the generator. This example shows that it is possible to use the value of an ant property and pass it as generator argument (in this case the value of ant property someAntProperty that is accessible by name arg1).

<ng.jetgen.src class="dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.test.jet.generated.JetGenerator"
               file="JetGenSrcTask.txt"
               failonerror="true">
  <jetIncludes dir="../templates" includes="**/*Generator.jet" />
  <javaIncludes dir="../src" includes="**/*.java" />
  
  <argument name="someArg" value="123" />
  <argument name="arg1" value="${someAntProperty}" />
</ng.jetgen.src>

ng.javagen.src

The ng.javagen.src task runs a java generator that is delivered as source and will be compiled first. The java source file(s) to compile are specified by nested includes tag(s) that follow the fileset concept of ant.

Attribute Description Required
class The fully-qualified class name of the class to run. It must implement dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.ant.IJavaGenTemplate Yes
file The output file either absolute or relative to the output directory specified in the context of this code generator. A default output file will be taken when omitted. No
failonerror Flag to indicate whether to halt the build in case of an error. The default value is true. No, defaults to true.
Nested Elements Description Required
includes Fileset(s) defining java source files to compile. Yes
argument An argument consists of a name and value (both String) and is passed to the generator. The number of specified arguments is not restricted. No

Examples:

This example runs the java generator defined by the class attribute after compiling it. The java source files to compile are defined by nested includes tags. 

<ng.javagen.src class="dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.test.generator.JavaGenSrcTestGenerator"
                file="JavaGenSrcTask.txt"
                failonerror="false">
  <includes dir="../src" includes="dreisoft/tresos/generator/ng/api/test/generator/JavaGenSrcTestGenerator.java" />

  <argument name="someArg" value="abc_" />
  <argument name="arg1" value="${someAntProperty}" />
</ng.javagen.src>

ng.property

This task executes an xpath expression and sets the result to the defined ant property.

Attribute Description Required
name The name of the property to set. Yes
xpath An arbitrary xpath expression to be executed on the underlying DCtxt. Yes
dctxt The name of a module configuration to which the DCtxt is set when the XPath will be invoked. If this attribute is omitted, the DCtxt will be set to the root context. No
override Defines whether an existing property with the same name should be overwritten (true | false). No, defaults to true.

Examples:

This example sets an ant property with name propertytest_x to the value of the General/Test node under the module configuration ModuleConfig1. 

<ng.property name="propertytest_x" dctxt="ModuleConfig1" xpath="General/Test" override="false" />

ng.setgeneratorvar

The ng.setgeneratorvar task is similar to the ng.property task but sets the result of the xpath expression into a generator variable instead of an ant property.

Attribute Description Required
name The name of the generator variable to set. Yes
xpath An arbitrary xpath expression to be executed on the underlying DCtxt. Yes
dctxt The name of a module configuration to which the DCtxt is set when the XPath will be invoked. If this attribute is omitted, the DCtxt will be set to the root context. No
override Defines whether an existing variable with the same name should be overwritten (true | false). No, defaults to true.

Examples:

Sets the generator variable generatorvartest_6 to the result of the given xpath expression. If there already exists a variable with the same name it will not be overwritten due to override="false". 

<ng.setgeneratorvar name="generatorvartest_6" xpath="text:split('a,b,c,d,e', ',')[3]" override="false"/>

ng.getgeneratorvar

The ng.getgeneratorvar task reads a generator variable and set it to an ant property.

Attribute Description Required
name The name of the generator variable to get. Yes
property Name of the ant property to set. Yes
override Defines whether an existing ant property with the same name should be overwritten (true | false). No, defaults to true.

Examples:

Reads the value of the generator variable generatorvartest_7 and set it to the ant property myProperty. If an ant property already exists with the same name it will be overwritten as long as the override attribute is not set to false. If there is no variable with the defined name or its value is null the ant property is set to null. After the assignment the ant property can be used in the build script, e.g. can be printed via the ant echo task. 

<ng.getgeneratorvar name="generatorvartest_7" property="myProperty" />
<echo message="Value: ${myProperty}" />

Example

Example ant buildfile: 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>

<project name="tresos" default="all" basedir=".">

  <target name="all">
    <property name="sourcePath" value="src"/>
    <property name="headerPath" value="include"/>

    <!-- Query model to calculate Ant property -->
    <ng.property name="useDet" xpath="node:exists(as:modconf('Det')[1])"/>

    <!-- Generate CanIf_Cfg.c via JavaGen Engine -->
    <ng.javagen class="CanIfCfg_c" file="${sourcePath}/CanIf_Cfg.c"/>

    <!-- Generate CanIf_Cfg.h via JetGenEngine -->
    <ng.jetgen class="CanIfCfg_h" file="${headerPath}/CanIf_Cfg.h">
      <argument name="useDet" value="${usDet}"/>
    </ng.jetgen>

  </target>
</project>
